= Work and Energy =

== TL;DR ==

*Work done by a constant force*
{{$
W = Fs\cos{\theta}
}}$
*Work done by a variable force*
{{$
W = \overline{F_x}\Delta x
}}$
*Kinetic energy*
{{$
K = \frac{1}{2}mv^2
}}$
*Work-energy theorem*
{{$
\Delta K = W
}}$
*Gravitational potential energy*
{{$
U = mgy
}}$
*Mechanical energy*
{{$
E = K + U
}}$
*Conservation of mechanical energy*
{{$
E = K + U = [\text{constant}]
}}$
*Conservative force*
    The work done by the force is zero for any roundtrip.
*Work done by a conservative force*:
{{$
W = U_1 - U_2
}}$
*Potential energy of a spring*
{{$
U = \frac{1}{2}kx^2
}}$
*Average power*
{{$
\overline{P} = \frac{W}{\Delta t}
}}$
*Instantaneous power*
{{$
P = \lim_{\Delta t \to 0} \frac{W}{\Delta t}
}}$
*Mechanical power delivered by a force*
{{$
P = Fv~cos{\theta}
}}$

== Work ==

{{$
W = \vec{F} \cdot \vec{\Delta x}
}}$

== Work as a Variable Force ==

Work done by a variable force

{{$
W = \overline{\vec{F}} \cdot \vec{\Delta x}
}}$

== Kinetic Energy ==

Kinetic energy

{{$
K = \frac{1}{2}mv^2
}}$

Work-energy theorem

{{$
\Delta K = W
}}$

== Potential Energy ==

Potential energy in a gravitational field

{{$
U = mgh
}}$

Mechanical energy

{{$
E = K + U
}}$

Conservation of mechanical energy

{{$
E = K + U = [constant]
}}$

== Potential Energy of a Conservative Force ==

Potential energy of a spring

{{$
U = \frac{1}{2}kx^2
}}$

== Other Forms of Energy ==

== Power ==

Average power

{{$
\overline{P} = \frac{W}{\Delta t}
}}$

Instantaneous power

{{$
P = \lim_{\Delta t \to 0} \frac{W}{\Delta t}
}}$

Power delivered by a force

{{$
P = \vec{F} \cdot \vec{v}
}}$
